newsitem.title: USA: Hyundai's Axil unit to make Windows NT computers.
newsitem.headline: Hyundai's Axil unit to make Windows NT computers.

text.p: Axil Computer Inc. on Monday will unveil a line of high-end server computers based on Microsoft Corp's Windows NT software standard.

Until now, Axil, the American computer unit of Korean-based Hyundai Corp., has made computers based on the Unix software standard. By making machines based on Windows NT, Axil will chase a much more rapidly growing market, the company said.

Axil makes servers, the type of computers that store and shuffle information through computer networks. Its machines have been based on microprocessors and software from Sun Microsystems Inc., a maker of mid-range Unix computer systems.

The new Axil machines, dubbed Northridge, use up to eight Pentium Pro microprocessors from Intel Corp. and are designed to store massive corporate databases. Depending on the configuration, prices range up to $150,000, the company said.
Axil joins a growing list of midrange computer companies that are making so-called Wintel machines, which are based on software standards from Microsoft and hardware standards from Intel.
In recent years, companies such have Hewlett-Packard Co., Digital Equipment Corp. and International Business Machines Corp. have focused increasingly on Wintel computers for corporate markets.
